timeline.bodyText: This class is probably not a great idea. For one it allows a user to add elements to it after it's been closed. The way I got around it in the onnx runtime API was by returning a carrier class that was AutoCloseable, but also immutable. See https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/57468c651c5b9bfc9a0f37c548203891e088f71a/java/src/main/java/ai/onnxruntime/OrtSession.java#L613
timeline.author: Craigacp

replies.bodyText: This class is only used for unit tests and I just moved it from its previous location in TestUtil, as it was the only utility remaining
replies.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText: Ah ok, I'd missed it was in the test code. We might want to consider doing something for the return value of session.run anyway as it is a bit irritating. Not that I'm too happy with how it turned out for onnxruntime, but it does work and it's safe.
replies.author: Craigacp

replies.bodyText: I agree, it is irritating. We should address that but let’s do it in another PR
replies.author: karllessard

timeline.bodyText: Does this call check that the size is larger than the required size for the shape & dtype?
timeline.author: Craigacp

replies.bodyText: I think the native part validate it but I can add a unit test to confirm this
replies.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText:
Ok, so after some investigation, I can see that the native call returns null if the buffer is smaller than the required size (a larger buffer is accepted though so we should preserve that behaviour) or if it fails to allocate the tensor for any other reason.
In TF 1.15, a NullPointerException was explicitly thrown in such case, which was a bit odd. @saudet changed it to a IllegalStateException in the JavaCPP version, which is better, but still misleading in case the mistake comes from a user-provided parameter (there is actually no way to know it from the native call).
So I've added an explicit check on the minimum tensor size requirement and now throw an IllegalArgumentException if that check does not pass. This is only possible with fixed-length datatypes, as we don't know the size of the elements for variable-length datatypes (TString factories will take care of this).
replies.author: karllessard

revised_code.chunk:
diff --git a/tensorflow-core/tensorflow-core-api/src/main/java/org/tensorflow/Tensor.java b/tensorflow-core/tensorflow-core-api/src/main/java/org/tensorflow/Tensor.java
index 7b272b3d..67c2eb30 100644
--- a/tensorflow-core/tensorflow-core-api/src/main/java/org/tensorflow/Tensor.java
+++ b/tensorflow-core/tensorflow-core-api/src/main/java/org/tensorflow/Tensor.java

@@ -66,6 +66,7 @@ public final class Tensor<T extends TType> implements AutoCloseable {
    * @param dtype datatype of the tensor
    * @param shape shape of the tensor
    * @return an allocated but uninitialized tensor
+   * @throws IllegalStateException if tensor failed to be allocated
    */
   public static <T extends TType> Tensor<T> of(DataType<T> dtype, Shape shape) {
     return of(dtype, shape, shape.size() * dtype.byteSize());

timeline.author: Craigacp
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -515,22 +502,15 @@ /** * Create a {@link TFloat64} constant with data from the given buffer. * - *

Creates a constant with the given shape by copying elements from the buffer (starting from - * its current position) into the tensor. For example, if {@code shape = {2,3} } (which represents - * a 2x3 matrix) then the buffer must have 6 elements remaining, which will be consumed by this - * method. - * * @param scope is a scope used to add the underlying operation. * @param shape the tensor shape. * @param data a buffer containing the tensor data. * @return a double constant * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the tensor shape is not compatible with the buffer - * @deprecated use {@link Ops#val(Tensor) Ops.constant(Tensor<TFloat64>)} instead */ @Endpoint
